title: What AI Takes When You Aren't Looking
subtitle: Identify the cognitive skills you're trading for speed and reclaim your pattern intuition with a single diagnostic prompt.
author: Ilia Karelin
content_html:
Few people examine the cognitive trades made when using AI. Every time you hand a task to a system, you create a quiet exchange. Something becomes easier. Something becomes less exercised. Over a month or a year, these exchanges add up, yet they rarely receive attention.

In this piece we will:

  • Offer a way to surface the skills you may be practising less often.

  • Use one prompt that encourages self-examination rather than maximisation.

  • Consider how AI might expose gaps in reasoning without dictating what to do about them.

Identify what you stop doing when a system steps in. What do you stop doing when a system steps in? Which habits of thought no longer receive repetition? This approach avoids ideology. It focuses on your own cognitive patterns and what they require to stay alive.

This week’s Slow AI prompt comes from , who writes Prosper, a publication for professionals trying to build thinking systems rather than prompt collections. This post aims to show how AI provides a diagnostic tool for personal blind spots.

Skills fade slowly. Silence is usually the first sign.

Slow AI is a shared space for reflection. Posts are free. Paid subscriptions support the work.

Step by step

Try this prompt with your AI tool of choice:

If you could teach me one thing I lose by relying on you, what would it be. What skill or way of thinking am I trading away each time I ask you instead of struggling through it myself.

Set boundaries before you begin. Ask for specifics, not sweeping statements. Request that the system avoids moral claims or certainty about cognitive decline. Make it clear you want one capability illustrated through a concrete example. Keep personal details out of the request. Interpretation and judgement remain your responsibility.

Choose a real task. Something you recently asked the system to tidy, summarise, rewrite, or decide. Ask for a description of the cognitive step you skipped. Ask for a clear moment in which that step usually appears when you work unaided. Then read the reply slowly.

If you are new to Slow AI, here is our first invitation.

A moment from

As you guys might know, Opus 4.5 was recently released, and I decided to use it for this exact prompt. What I got back was obvious and shocking to me at the same time, believe it or not.

Just to give you the history behind Claude’s answer, I’ve had my previous chats with Claude where I fed questions to it about coding, debugging, data, Structured query language (SQL), strategic decisions, etc.

What Claude told me was this: The skill I’m trading away is pattern intuition - the kind you only build by struggling through problems yourself.

When I go to Claude first, I get something coherent almost immediately. It arrives fully formed. I never have to sit with the question long enough for my own mind to start making unexpected connections.

Claude gave me a specific example that hit hard: debugging. When I hit an error, my instinct now is to paste the stack trace and ask. Claude gives me the fix. I move on. Obviously, with things like debugging, Claude has no idea how long I’ve sat with a particular problem before I sent that 1st prompt to Claude. Nevertheless - pattern intuition is such an important skill to obtain in life!

It’s also important to go through the slow process of forming a hypothesis, testing it, being wrong, adjusting. That’s where pattern intuition comes from. That’s how you learn to recognize where to look next time, before you even understand why. The fix is the byproduct. The real output is supposed to be a mental model of how these systems fail.

Same with SQL, in my case. When Claude writes the query, I get the answer. When I struggle through it myself, I’m forced to think about the shape of my data - what questions are even askable, what relationships I hadn’t noticed. Again: the query isn’t the point. The thinking is.

The cost isn’t visible in any single interaction. It’s cumulative. A thousand small moments where I could have waited, sat with discomfort a bit longer, and didn’t.

What to do with it

If you want to share:

  • Name the single insight that felt accurate about the skill you tend to skip.

  • Identify the first point where the response drifted into assumption, and describe how you refined it.

  • Describe what changed in your own thinking once you examined the exchange without leaning on productivity as the measure.

The purpose of this prompt is to understand the conditions under which your own thinking strengthens or weakens.

Why this matters

Tools change behaviour before it's noticed. Delegation becomes a habit. What once helped you develop judgement or patience becomes optional. The shift is often invisible because the result still looks polished.

If you can tell the difference between healthy delegation and premature outsourcing, you put yourself in a stronger position. You can let AI handle what does not require your judgment and keep the tasks that shape your competence. You protect the parts of your work that depend on friction.

Slow AI encourages professionals to treat these systems as prompts for self-knowledge. Useful when well-chosen. Clear when questioned. Always secondary to your own objectives and the skills that make your thinking distinct.

By Ilia Karelin

From How to Minimise AI Hallucinations in Research and Writing

and I were impressed by how consistently readers located the risk in human judgement rather than model failure.

framed this with precision by naming the different internal voices people bring to AI use. His point was simple and sharp. Hallucinations surface when reassurance, structure, or coherence are mistaken for truth. When those voices blur together, checking stops. When they are named, judgement tightens.

extended this by introducing authority drift. The issue is not just incorrect output, but misplaced responsibility. When systems sound confident and relational, users verify less. Error becomes harder to see because authority has quietly shifted away from the human.

grounded the discussion in practice with his example of fabricated company case studies. What mattered was not that the tool invented details, but how plausibly and persistently it defended them. Verification only returned when Mack forced the system to show its sources. Until then, confidence carried the claim.

Taken together, these comments converge on the same point. Hallucinations are sustained by trust, tone, and speed. Slow AI matters because it reasserts where responsibility sits, before confidence becomes compliance.

We read and respond to all your comments.
